title: Newcastle Knights secure third straight NRLW finals appearance | The Singleton Argus
body_text:
The Newcastle Knights have locked down a third straight finals appearance in NRLW with a resounding 38-6 win over North Queensland in the competition's final round in Townsville on Saturday.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Now, the back-to-back defending champions wait to see if they have earned hosting rights for the semi-finals next weekend.
Newcastle ran in seven tries compared to the Cowboys' one, and could have had more.
The 32-point win provisionally elevated the Knights into second place on points differential.
They improved to 12 points to be on level footing with the Sydney Roosters and Cronulla. The trio are two points adrift of leaders Brisbane, who thumped the Dragons 44-14 earlier on Saturday in Townville.
The Roosters play fifth-placed Parramatta (10 points) on Sunday at 3pm. A loss for the Roosters, who are playing for the minor premiership, would give the Knights a home semi-final.
The Knights took an 18-0 lead into half-time after another dominant display built on defensive grit and attacking efficiency.
For the second week in a row, second-rower Yasmin Clydsdale broke the game open early when the Scone school teacher hit a hole through some flimsy Cowboys defence and powered across the try line in the fifth minute after back-to-back sets for the Knights.
Prop Tayla Predebon, who came into the starting side in place of injured Rima Butler (knee), then showed her sheer strength and determination to drag four Cowboys players across the line and score in the 11th minute.
The second try came after a penalty for a crusher tackle on Jesse Southwell, that left Bree Chester on report and had the Knights within 10 metres of the try line.
Tenika Willison continued a break-out rookie campaign in NRLW with a try in the 17th minute after Knights fullback Tamika Upton cut straight through North Queensland's line and found the Kiwi sevens star on the left edge with a cut-out pass.
Knights halfback Jesse Southwell was successful with all three conversion kicks in the first half.
It was more of the same in the second half.
Upton was again involved when Abigail Roache, who had dropped the ball across the try line in the first half, was played perfectly into a gap by her fullback to score in the 40th minute.
Chester struck back for the hosts with an individual effort in the 43rd minute and Kirra Dibb converted to have the scoreline 26-6.
But it was one-way traffic again from there.
Willison crossed for her second try in the 47th minute after Clydsdale, who ran a game-high 233 metres, did well to offload on the try line.
Powerful winger Sheridan Gallagher then produced back-to-back tries in the 58th and 61st minutes.
Teenage utility Evie Jones almost added another with less than two minutes remaining but dropped the ball over the line.
Southwell kicked two conversions in the second half to finish the game with 10 points.
Knights pathways product Evah McEwen, 18, was the third teenager to be given her NRLW debut by coach Ben Jeffries this year.
The NSW under-19 second-rower produced a solid 48-minute performance off the bench.
It was a successful day for the Knights with their NSW Rugby League Women's Premiership side beating minor premiers Wentworthville 20-18 in a semi-final showdown at Leichhardt Oval to secure a grand final appearance next weekend.
Super Rugby convert Isabella Waterman scored a hat-trick of tries and Jules Kirkpatrick also got on the scoresheet for the Knights.
Multi-sport talent Jess Gentle, who helped guide Charlestown Azzurri to the NPLW Northern NSW Football championship last Sunday night, kicked two conversions.
